column6: Interactions with water as a shared resource
column8: Water stewardship: A landscape approach in the uMzimkhulu water catchment with WWF
column13: The partnership between CHEP and WWF in the uMzimkhulu catchment aims to safeguard water resources and promote sustainable natural resource management. This project secures the Southern Drakensberg water source area, providing for over four million downstream users and KwaZulu-Natal's economic hub. The partnership's initial phase will span 18 months and focus on improving water access, sustainable rangeland management, biodiversity, and effective catchment coordination.
column20: Water conservation, Sustainable management, Catchment protection

column6: Interactions with water as a shared resource
column13: The service centre of CHEP TÃÂ¼rkiye in Ankara successfully installed a rainwater harvesting system. This initiative has resulted in conserving 540,000kL of water over three years. Implementing this system provides many benefits, including environmental, financial, and operational advantages.
column20: Rainwater harvesting, Water conservation, Operational Efficiency

column6: Interactions with water as a shared resource
column13: CHEP New Zealand successfully delivered a water recycling treatment system at the Penrose service centre. The system was an excellent opportunity to reduce water and costs, leading to a 90% reduction of water discharged annually. This new system also makes washing processes less energy and resource-intensive.\t
column20: Water recycling, Resource conservation, Cost reduction

column7: Withdrawal from municipal water supplies or other water utilities: 213 megalitres

column13: Before purchase, the timber farms were in poor condition and relations with the local community needed to be more favourable. Brambles has gone beyond the rigorous FSC certification process, enhanced the employees' working conditions and implemented leading forestry management practices. It will ensure that the previously degrading plantations thrive sustainably.
column20: Sustainable forestry, Community engagement, FSC certification

column6: Operational sites owned, leased, managed in, or adjacent to, protected areas and areas of high biodiversity value outside protected areas
column7: For Brambles, pioneering regenerative supply chains means nature-positive actions. In practice, this means preserving, restoring and revitalising natural systems. Our unique vertically integrated African business provides rare opportunities for direct nature-positive action with the community as a key stakeholder.

column6: Significant impacts of activities, produces, and services on biodiversity
column13: Maintain 100% sustainable sourcing Ã¢ÂÂ¢ Grow the CoC programme throughout the world's forestry supply chains Ã¢ÂÂ¢ Enable the sustainable growth of two trees for every tree we use

column6: Significant impacts of activities, produces, and services on biodiversity
column13: Brambles aims to set a global benchmark for sourcing certified sustainable wood for our products while promoting forest regeneration. Our Forest Positive strategy is straightforward: by 2025, we will enable the sustainable growth of two trees for everyone we need.
column20: Forest regeneration, Sustainable growth, Environmental impact

column6: Significant impacts of activities, produces, and services on biodiversity
column13: Value-added philanthropy involves investing in afforestation, reforestation, and conservation projects that benefit local communities by restoring native forests and providing forest-linked income opportunities in sustainable agriculture.

ALA BoOL and CHEP are working on a forestry regeneration project in Tabasco, Mexico. They plan to reforest 6,000 hectares of land and create sustainable income for local communities. This initiative rejuvenates former ranching land into thriving forests and leaves a lasting impact on local communities through sustainable and reliable income for landowners.
column20: Forestry regeneration, Sustainable income, Community Impact

column13: Brambles' strategic approach to achieving our Forest Positive Targets includes a regenerative forestry programme that enables the sustainable growth of two trees for every one used. This approach encourages diverse methods of increasing forest mass beyond our operational boundary. This approach will yield a substantial and enduring positive impact on our business, society, and the environment, and it requires multi-stakeholder collaborations for success.
column20: Regenerative forestry, Sustainable growth, Multi-stakeholder collaboration

column8: Regenerative partnership with WeForest in the Mafinga Hills, Zambia
column13: Brambles has formed a regenerative partnership with WeForest to promote sustainable restoration and management in the Mafinga District of Zambia. The initiative involves creating a Community Forest Area that will be managed sustainably to safeguard and restore forests while supporting local communities. This project will address widespread forest degradation by promoting good forest stewardship and reinforce the role of the local partner organisation, the Wildlife and Environment Conservation Society of Zambia, as a long-term advocate for the cause.
column20: Forest restoration, Community management, Sustainable stewardship

column6: IUCN Red List species and national conversation list species with habitats in areas affected by operations
column13: The Southern Drakensberg Vulture Conservation Project works with Wildlife ACT to safeguard endangered vultures in KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa, near CHEP SSA timber farms. Vultures are essential for a healthy ecosystem, but their numbers are dwindling due to poisoning, collisions, and illegal trade. The project protects their habitats, responds to poisonings, educates communities, and advocates for better law enforcement.
column20: Vulture conservation, Ecosystem protection, Community Education

column13: Afforestation from Carbon Credits is purchased to achieve our Scope 1 carbon neutrality target. It creates new forest mass and offsets emissions. However, the number of trees and the subsequent impact on our Forest Positive Target is modest.\t

column7: The location-based indirect GHG emissions: 16,407 ktCO2e
Setting SBTs covering 100% of our Scope 1 and 2 and over 90% of our Scope 3 emissions by 2025

column8: CHEP and PepsiCo Brazil clock 1 million kilometres travelled through shared trips
column13: The collaboration has improved supply chain efficiencies in FY21, FY22, and FY23 and reduced carbon emissions through optimising transportationÃ¢ÂÂreaching an impressive 1 million kilometres in shared trips, translating to a reduction of over 800 tonnes of fuel-related emissions. The project has strengthened the successful commercial relationship, and the collaboration is evolving beyond mileage efficiencies, with a portion of the transport now utilising alternative fuels and renewable energy.
column20: Supply chain efficiency, Carbon emissions reduction, Collaboration

column8: Sainsbury's and CHEP's partnership reduces empty kilometres and CO2 emissions.
column13: In the UK, CHEP collaborated with Sainsbury's Distribution Centre in Daventry to eliminate 1,000 truck trips and save over 40,000 km in transport movements. This initiative eliminated unnecessary pallet movements and decreased pallet supply collection and delivery distances.

Brambles plans to achieve net zero carbon emissions by 2040 through its SBTs. The Supply Chain team developed an interactive tool, the Decarbonisation Pathways Model, to help meet Scope 1, 2 and 3 targets.
column20: Carbon emissions reduction, Decarbonisation tool, Net zero target

column6: Nitrogen oxides (NOx), sulfur oxides (SOx), and other significant air emissions
Waste generation and significant waste-related impacts
column13: GIWA GmbH, our German partner in plastic solutions, has been fundamental in the most significant sustainability benchmark of any product range in our history Ã¢ÂÂ the EU LMS plastic range is now entirely produced with 100% post-consumer upcycled plastic. The GIWA team embraced this recycled material ambition for existing products (the new Q+ RDU) and is setting the standard for future Brambles plastic products.
column20: Plastic upcycling, Post-consumer plastic, Sustainable solutions

column8: Brambles' solutions to achieve zero product waste to landfill
column13: Reduce: Reduce damage, Improve durability; reuse: Minimise scrapping, Maximise reclaim of damaged materials; recycle: to products like biochar, new lumber, garden mulch, and compost; recover: through waste-to-energy technologies; landfill: not aligned with the target, actively seeking solutions for change.

The new Q+ static plastic quarter pallet, made from 100% post-consumer plastic pallets, eliminates the need for virgin plastic and helps reduce plastic pollution. CHEP recovers and upcycles 1.5kg of plastic waste for every new Q+ pallet. Ideal for customers who prioritise sustainability and compliance with upcoming EU regulations on one-way and tertiary packaging.
column20: Plastic waste reduction, Upcycled plastic, Pollution prevention
